conclusion: Analyze the refraction of light through the hemispherical shell.
The hemispherical shell has an inner radius R and an outer radius √2R.
A parallel beam of light with a cross-sectional radius R is incident on the inner surface, parallel to the axis of symmetry.
The light rays strike the inner surface at various points.
The angle of incidence θ_i at the inner surface can be determined using the geometry of the hemisphere.
Snell's Law: n1 sin θ_i = n2 sin θ_r.
n1 is the refractive index of the medium outside the shell (air, n1 = 1).
n2 is the refractive index of the transparent medium of the shell.
For a point on the edge of the beam, the angle of incidence θ_i is 90° (grazing incidence).
For points closer to the axis, θ_i decreases.
The light rays refract again as they exit the outer surface of the shell.
The angle of incidence at the outer surface θ'_i is related to θ_r from the inner surface.
Snell's Law at the outer surface: n2 sin θ'_i = n1 sin θ'_r.
The radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface is determined by the maximum angle θ'_r at which light exits the shell.
Using the geometry of the hemisphere, the radius r of the circular boundary can be found using trigonometric relations.
The relationship between the radii and angles can be derived using the geometry of the hemisphere and the refractive indices.
The final radius r of the circular boundary on the outer surface is given by r = √2R sin θ'_r.
Using the refractive index n and the geometry, we find r = √2R/n.
The radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface of the hemispherical shell where light rays are transmitted is r = √2R/n.
